key_insight: State-of-the-art vision-language models (VLMs) can reliably replicate human binary perceptual judgments and be used as perceptual judges to align image compression to human preferences, replacing or supplementing specialized psycho-visual networks.
problem_solved: Bridging the gap between distortion-driven compression (e.g., MSE) and human subjective preference by providing a scalable perceptual judge that correlates with human evaluations.
method: Use VLMs to score pairwise image quality or compute embedding-based perceptual distances as a proxy for human preference.
Integrate VLM-derived signals as a loss or ranking objective into compression model training to encourage human-aligned reconstructions.
Validate alignment with human binary preference studies and compare against traditional metrics (MSE, PSNR) and existing perceptual losses.
impact: Provides a practical, scalable route to develop compression models that produce images humans prefer without collecting massive psycho-visual datasets; lowers barrier for human-aligned perceptual objectives in ML systems.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: input image → compressor → reconstructed image → VLM scoring → loss/backprop loop
Bar chart: human preference rates comparing MSE, traditional perceptual loss, and VLM-based loss
Side-by-side qualitative comparisons of reconstructions (MSE vs VLM-aligned) with human-choice overlays
Scatter plot: correlation of VLM scores vs human binary judgments (preference probability)
paper_title: VLIC: Vision-Language Models As Perceptual Judges for Human-Aligned Image Compression
paper_authors: Kyle Sargent, Ruiqi Gao, Philipp Henzler, Charles Herrmann, Aleksander Holynski
